Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Biobased Platform for the Sustainable Molecular Design and Controlled Synthesis of Block Polymers from Renewable Feedstocks
Award.AbstractNarration:
Under the support of the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professors Thomas H. Epps, III and Michael T. Klein of the University of Delaware and Professor Joseph Stanzione of Rowan University will collaborate to develop synthetic pathways and computational tools for converting lignin-based bio-oils to polymers. This research aims to address the grand challenge of manufacturing new plastic materials from natural and renewable resources, without depleting food or other commercial resource production. The lignin-based polymers to be produced through this research have potential uses in paints, surface coatings, and other composite materials. This project provides research opportunities to students-including underrepresented undergraduate and economically-disadvantaged high school students-in acollaborative laboratory setting and exposes students to modern concepts for making new 'biorenewable' plastics.

This project focuses on developing efficient and cost-effective approaches to generate 'designer plastics' from a renewable resource based on lignin, an inexpensive and natural waste product of pulp and paper industry. The main tasks of this project include: 1) computational modeling of lignin-based bio-oil composition as a function of pyrolysis conditions and variability in wood composition/source; 2) functionalization of the major components of bio-oils separately or collectively to generate versatile monomer libraries from lignin waste streams; 3) synthesis of homopolymers (from a single type of lignin-modified monomers) or heteropolymers (from lignin-modified monomers in bio-oil mixtures); 4) kinetic studies of the heteropolymer formation by free-radical polymerization; and 5) design and preparation of tunable nanostructures of block copolymers that are potentially useful as thermoplastic elastomers and pressure-sensitive adhesives.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The use of bio-based and bio-inspired feedstocks for the facile synthesis of polymers unlocks potentially sustainable (more environmentally friendly) routes to the fabrication of next-generation materials, membranes, and devices. In this project, lignin was employed as the base feedstock, and the use of depolymerization products from the chemical transformation of lignin was examined.  The choice of lignin was because of (1) its aromatic nature that can enable the synthesis of polymers with structural stability for a diverse array of applications, similar to the varied components in trees (and plants), (2) its current under-utilization as a waste product from industrial and agricultural properties, where it is routinely burned or thrown away, (3) its high abundance with ~70 million tons produced as a waste product, and (4) its relatively low cost. Furthermore, the lignin-derived and lignin-inspired molecules isolated and synthesized herein had polymerization rates and macromolecular characteristics that were similar to, or in some cases surpassed, those of petrochemical-based incumbents. The additional functionality present in the bio-based polymers led to enhanced selective solubility, chemical resistance, adhesion, and materials tunability, using materials and processes that have promise from an economic and environmental sustainability perspective.

 

Intellectual Merit:

Through the National Science Foundation’s SusChEM program, several novel, bio-based, high-performance polymers were synthesized. This task was accomplished through a multidisciplinary approach that integrated green chemistry, bio-based feedstock composition, understanding of structure-property relationships, and renewable (bio-based) resource utilization.  Lignin, which is a common waste product from the pulp & paper industry and biorefineries, was used as the major renewable feedstock and inspiration for the materials. As a result of the work conducted in this project, a new class of chemical building blocks has been generated from sustainable and renewable feedstocks in a manner that is readily translatable to commercial products.  Additionally, an understanding of feedstock-structure-property relationships was gained that then informed targeted structural modifications – enabling the synthesis and characterization of advanced materials. For example, pressure-sensitive adhesives were made directly from raw popular wood with minimal separations, and they tested favorably in terms of performance characteristics against commercial products.  Furthermore, new thermally curable adhesives and coatings were generated by leveraging the inherent functionality found in native and technical biomass.  These coatings/adhesives have application as automotive protectants, anti-fouling coatings, paints, and other products. Key results were highlighted in multiple publications in the peer-reviewed literature, multiple patents and patent applications, oral and poster presentations to the scientific and local community, and collaborative scientific activities with other academic and industrial groups, including small businesses.

 

Broader Impacts:

In addition to the design and synthesis of new, high-performance materials from bio-based (renewable and sustainable) feedstocks, major results associated with this project led to the formation of a startup company, Lignolix LLC, that has won stand-alone funding from other sources and several awards/honors.  Furthermore, project personnel engaged in a variety of educational and outreach activities that had a substantial and positive impact on the community.  For example, researchers hosted economically disadvantaged high school students and provided eight-week research internships that focused on the use of bio-based feedstocks for the fabrication of new coatings and dental materials.  During the course of this project, the overall high school internship program directly impacted approximately 30 students.  The participation of other project personnel was leveraged to staff a booth a local Arts and Science Festival sponsored by a nonprofit organization. Over 300 low-income K-12 students attended the event to participate in hands-on science, technology, engineering, arts, and mathematics (STEAM) learning, working with circuit boards containing re-purposed components from bananas, single-use plastics, and other materials.
